awd_titl_txt: CNS Core: Small: Collaborative: Towards Surge-Resilient Hybrid RF/VLC Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
The successful deployment of smart city-scale wireless services, such as the Internet of Things (IoT), hinges on the presence of a reliable communication infrastructure that can pervasively connect both human and machine-type devices. In order to support the traffic anticipated from an IoT ecosystem, the wireless infrastructure must be resilient to the surge of traffic that can result from a plethora of events that range from hot-spot events and random failures to natural disasters and targeted attacks. The goal of this research is to develop a novel wireless network architecture that leverages both radio frequency (RF) and visible light communication (VLC) to provide resilient and pervasive connectivity. The developed architecture and associated frameworks will bring together novel, cross-disciplinary ideas from communication theory, learning, and game theory to explore the fundamental theoretical and experimental challenges of a hybrid and resilient RF/VLC network. The research is coupled with a comprehensive educational plan that includes new course material, tutorials, and large-scale involvement of graduate and undergraduate students in research related to resilient communications and networking.

This research will introduce a novel framework for designing, analyzing, and optimizing hybrid RF/VLC communications, in the presence of failures, hotspots, and natural disasters. The key technical contributions will include: 1) Novel scheduling algorithms uniquely tailored towards RF/VLC systems that can maximize the number of users with available connectivity, in the presence of traffic surges; 2) Effective transmission mechanisms based on non-orthogonal multiple access that can enhance the spectral efficiency of flash crowds; 3) Resilient self-organizing algorithms, based on game theory and reinforcement learning, that exploit feedback across radio access technologies to enable intelligent and resilient resource management in the presence of incomplete information; and 4) Practical RF/VLC experiments that will be used to validate the proposed research and bridge the gap between theory and practice.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research project provided the scientific foundations needed to design more resilient communication systems that can deliver high-speed connectivity to areas that have limited connectivity or to hotspots/congested situations. In particular,  the intellectual merits included the development of innovative techniques that can be used to jointly combined radio frequency (RF) wireless communication with visible light communication (VLC) to enhance connectivity. In this regard, the proposed research provided the necessary mathematical tools for designing, analyzing, and optimizing both RF and VLC systems, while also investigating their synergies. For instance, a key research outcome was the design of a system that can complement wireless communication at terahertz (THz) frequencies -- a key band for 6G systems -- with positioning from VLC systems to ensure a more reliable connectivity for indoor environments and applications like virtual reality. Through a synergistic mix of theory, simulations, and experiments, this research shed light on the achievable communication and positioning performance of VLC systems, providing new ways to exploit this technology in future communication networks. The developed mathematical tools have contributed to a better understanding on how to instill resilience and robustness in a system by designing communication-centric machine learning techniques. The developed techniques also advanced the field of machine learning by introducing innovative idea such as cross-environment learning whereby a machine learning agent can generalize across multiple environments. The project then demonstrated how such techniques can improve resilient communication in various networking settings including Cube satellie networks. The research also studied how interference in air-to-ground communication links that involve drones can be better managed to improve communication effectiveness. Moreover, the proposed research led to advances across interdisciplinary fields that include wireless communications, network science, machine learning, reinforcement learning, and optimization theory. The broader impacts included: a) Fostering a close collaboration between two major US institutions (Virginia Tech and North Carolina State University), b) Training graduate students on emerging topics in wireless technologies, an area that is a major priority for the United States, c) Disseminating the developed innovations to the broad research community via workshops, tutorials, keynote, seminars, summer schools, and online tools, and d) Outreach events to local schools that exposed a large population of students (including under-represented female minorities) to electrical engineering and wireless networking research.
